_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This risk management plan (RMP) updates our April 2015 RMP submittal. All sections of the RMP have been updated.


1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Bayer CropScience (BCS) Kansas City site is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. We regularly assess the risks associated with the use of chemicals in our manufacturing processes using tools such as Hazard and Operability studies and modeling programs, and we seek out ways in which to reduce those risks. The site has an established committee comprised of members with diverse backgrounds and areas of expertise that meets regularly to discuss accidental releases and opportunities for prevention. It is our policy to proactively implement appropriate measures to prevent possible releases. If such a release does occur, our highly-trained on-site emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. The site has maintained a long-standing working relationship with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Kansas City, Missouri emergency response community including HAZMAT 71 that ensures their support in the event of an unexpected release.


2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The primary activities at our facility are the manufacture and formulation of crop protection chemicals. There are seven regulated chemicals present at our facility above threshold quantities. These chemicals are essential raw materials for the production of crop protection products, and are: 1) carbon disulfide, 2) chlorine, 3) formaldehyde (solution), 4) hydrazine, 5) anhydrous hydrogen chloride, 6) methyl butene, and 7) phosphorus trichloride.


3. Accidental

Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The BCS Kansas City site has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. This manufacturing facility was designed and constructed generally in accordance with NFPA-30, which was in effect at the time of construction. A number of processes at our facility are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. The facility is also subject to the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC) under 40 CFR 112, the RCRA Preparedness and Prevention regulations and Contingency Plan and Emergency Procedures under Subpart C and D of 40 CFR 264, and EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements. In addition, the facility is also subject to the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard (CFATS) under 6 CFR 27.


4. Five-year Accident History

The BCS Kansas City site has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years; there have been no RMP reportable accidental releases during this period. 

5. Emergency Response Program

The BCS Kansas City site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. The site has an on-site emergency brigade comprised of approximately 60 employees providing coverage 24 hours per day and 365 days per year. The brigade is trained to mitigate fire, medical, hazardous material, and rescue emergencies. The site also has a trained Technician and Incident Command level HAZMAT team with approximately 12 employees available for emergencies when necessary. The HAZMAT team and emergency brigade provide initial response for any emergencies that may occur. To ensure proper

functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is reviewed annually and updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response strategy.


6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The BCS Kansas City site is regulated under CFATS and is in full compliance with security plan submittal requirements. Security upgrades have been made in accordance with the Site Security Plan and additional upgrades are constantly being evaluated. The site is currently replacing the site-wide fire alarm system; this alarm system provides highly-reliable, front-line notification in the event of fire, spill, or other emergencies. A facility siting study to account for the impacts of toxic releases and explosion overpressure on structures is also in progress. Additional high integrity safeguards using enhanced inerting and grounding systems are being installed to prevent flammable vapor explosions. Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) have been installed, ensuring very high reliability process control system safeguards. Finally, the site has nearly completed a complete replacement and upgrade of the Distributed Control System's (DCS) used in the RMP related production plants.
